Package mz

Class Bubble

java.lang.Object
mz.SortComparable
mz.Selection
mz.Bubble
All Implemented Interfaces:
SelectionInterface<Comparable>, Sort<Comparable>, SortFind<Comparable>, SortSwap<Comparable>
Direct Known Subclasses:
Cocktail, Gnome, IntroBubble, OddEven
public class Bubble extends Selection
Bubble Sort is a simple sorting algorithm that repeatedly compares adjacent elements and swaps them if they are in the wrong order. It works by repeatedly "bubbling" the largest (or smallest) element to its correct position in each iteration.

  • Constructor Details

    • Bubble

      public Bubble()
      Bubble Sort:
      Bubble Sort is a simple sorting algorithm that repeatedly compares adjacent elements and swaps them if they are in the wrong order. It works by repeatedly "bubbling" the largest (or smallest) element to its correct position in each iteration.

      Example:
      1. Start with an unsorted array of elements.
      2. Compare each pair of adjacent elements starting from the beginning of the array.
      3. If the elements are in the wrong order (e.g., the current element is greater than the next element for ascending order), swap them.
      4. Move to the next pair of adjacent elements and repeat steps 2-3.
      5. After the first pass, the largest (or smallest) element will be in its correct position at the end of the array.
      6. Repeat steps 2-5 for the remaining elements (excluding the last sorted element) until the entire array is sorted.
      Note:
      Bubble Sort gets its name from the way smaller (or larger) elements "bubble" to their correct positions during each iteration. In each pass, the largest (or smallest) element gradually moves towards the end (or beginning) of the array.

      Bubble Sort has a time complexity of O(n^2) in the average and worst cases. It is not considered an efficient sorting algorithm for large datasets due to its quadratic time complexity. However, it has the advantage of simplicity and ease of implementation.

      Property:
      Worst Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Best Case Complexity: O(n)
      Average Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Auxiliary Space: O(1)
      Stability: Yes
      See Also:

      Parameters:

    • bubbleInc

      protected void bubbleInc(Comparable[] array)
      bubbleInc that performs the Bubble Sort algorithm on an array of Comparable objects. The sorting is done in ascending order.
      • The method takes in an array of Comparable objects, array, and performs the Bubble Sort algorithm on it.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to type safety when using the compareTo method.
      • The method starts with defining the length of the array as n.
      • Two nested for loops are used for iterating over the elements of the array and comparing adjacent elements to perform the sorting.
      • The outer loop iterates from 0 to (n - 1) and represents the number of passes performed in the Bubble Sort algorithm.
      • The inner loop iterates from 1 to (n - i) - 1 and represents the range of elements to be compared in each pass. The (n - i) part is because the largest i elements are already sorted and placed at the end in each pass.
      • Inside the inner loop, an if condition is used to compare adjacent elements. If the element at index (j - 1) is greater than the element at index j, the elements are swapped to bring the smaller element towards the beginning of the array.
      • The swap method is called to swap the elements at indices (j - 1) and j.
      bubbleInc method implements the Bubble Sort algorithm to sort the given array of Comparable objects in ascending order. It repeatedly compares adjacent elements and swaps them if necessary until the array is sorted.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      See Also:
      • SortSwap.swap(Comparable[], int, int)

    • bubbleDec

      protected void bubbleDec(Comparable[] array)
      bubbleDec that performs the Bubble Sort algorithm on an array of Comparable objects. The sorting is done in descending order.
      • The method takes in an array of Comparable objects, array, and performs the Bubble Sort algorithm on it.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to type safety when using the compareTo method.
      • The method starts with defining the length of the array as n.
      • Two nested for loops are used for iterating over the elements of the array and comparing adjacent elements to perform the sorting.
      • The outer loop iterates from 0 to (n - 1) and represents the number of passes performed in the Bubble Sort algorithm.
      • The inner loop iterates from 1 to (n - i) - 1 and represents the range of elements to be compared in each pass. The (n - i) part is because the largest i elements are already sorted and placed at the end in each pass.
      • Inside the inner loop, an if condition is used to compare adjacent elements. If the element at index (j - 1) is smaller than the element at index j, the elements are swapped to bring the greater element towards the beginning of the array.
      • The swap method is called to swap the elements at indices (j - 1) and j.
      bubbleInc method implements the Bubble Sort algorithm to sort the given array of Comparable objects in descending order. It repeatedly compares adjacent elements and swaps them if necessary until the array is sorted.

    • bubbleInc

      protected void bubbleInc(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)
      bubbleInc that performs the Bubble Sort algorithm on an array of Comparable objects. The sorting is done in ascending order.
      • The method takes in an array of Comparable objects, array, and performs the Bubble Sort algorithm on it.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to type safety when using the compareTo method.
      • The method starts with defining the length of the array as right.
      • Two nested for loops are used for iterating over the elements of the array and comparing adjacent elements to perform the sorting.
      • The outer loop iterates from 0 to (right - 1) and represents the number of passes performed in the Bubble Sort algorithm.
      • The inner loop iterates from 1 to (right - i) - 1 and represents the range of elements to be compared in each pass. The (right - i) part is because the largest i elements are already sorted and placed at the end in each pass.
      • Inside the inner loop, an if condition is used to compare adjacent elements. If the element at index (j - 1) is greater than the element at index j, the elements are swapped to bring the smaller element towards the beginning of the array.
      • The swap method is called to swap the elements at indices (j - 1) and j.
      bubbleInc method implements the Bubble Sort algorithm to sort the given array of Comparable objects in ascending order. It repeatedly compares adjacent elements and swaps them if necessary until the array is sorted.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - the value in the array must be smaller than a right parameter.
      right - the value in the array must be greater than a left parameter.
      See Also:
      • SortSwap.swap(Comparable[], int, int)

    • bubbleDec

      protected void bubbleDec(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)

      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to type safety when using the compareTo method.
      • The method starts with defining the length of the array as right.
      • Two nested for loops are used for iterating over the elements of the array and comparing adjacent elements to perform the sorting.
      • The outer loop iterates from 0 to (right - 1) and represents the number of passes performed in the Bubble Sort algorithm.
      • The inner loop iterates from 1 to (right - i) - 1 and represents the range of elements to be compared in each pass. The (right - i) part is because the largest i elements are already sorted and placed at the end in each pass.
      • Inside the inner loop, an if condition is used to compare adjacent elements. If the element at index (j - 1) is smaller than the element at index j, the elements are swapped to bring the greater element towards the beginning of the array.
      • The swap method is called to swap the elements at indices (j - 1) and j.
